She worked harder than ever, expanding her knowledge of fruit and perfecting her bargaining skills, determined to build a successful business of her own.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she saved enough money to buy her own cart. She felt a surge of pride as she loaded it with her carefully selected fruits, ready to strike out on her own. The open road beckoned, promising freedom and the chance to build a future free from the constraints of her father's legacy.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut her prices. Fueled by a burning resentment, Della engaged in a fierce price war, determined to outmaneuver her competitor. She won, but the victory felt hollow, leaving her with a bitter taste in her mouth and a renewed sense of paranoia about those who would try to take advantage of her.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she discovered a hidden stash of bruised and damaged fruit in an abandoned orchard. She saw potential in the forgotten fruits, a chance to salvage something beautiful from what others had discarded. She meticulously cleaned and repaired them, finding a strange sense of satisfaction in bringing them back to life.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the whole basket, and that's my final offer.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, Della. It's a deal.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, let's get this basket loaded up.
      Della Plumstone -- "Right then, let's get this loaded up. I've got a long journey ahead of me.
      Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins per basket, haggle for a higher price, or walk away from the deal.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched in fascination as his father haggled with a gruff farmer over the price of a basket of apples. Cedric, small and unnoticed, slipped behind the farmer and subtly replaced a bruised apple with a perfect one from his own bag. His father, unaware of the switch, secured a better price, and Cedric, thrilled with his contribution, felt a surge of power.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he overheard a group of children boasting about their families' wealth. Feeling a pang of envy, Cedric decided to embellish his own story. He claimed his family owned a fleet of carriages, a grand estate, and a fortune in gold, all carefully crafted lies designed to impress. To his surprise, the children believed him, and Cedric reveled in the admiration he received.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he began to frequent the marketplace, not just as a customer but as a budding entrepreneur. He started by selling small trinkets and toys, quickly learning the art of persuasion. He discovered a knack for exaggerating the value of his goods, weaving tales of their origin and magical properties to entice buyers.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take over the family fruit stall. Cedric, eager to prove himself, decided to expand the business. He ventured beyond the marketplace, travelling to neighboring villages to purchase fruit directly from farmers. He skillfully negotiated prices, often exploiting the farmers' lack of knowledge or their desperation for quick cash.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a shrewd merchant who challenged his tactics. The merchant, a veteran of countless bartering sessions, saw through Cedric's tricks and refused to be swayed. This encounter, though frustrating, ignited a fire in Cedric. He vowed to refine his skills, to become even more cunning and elusive, to outsmart anyone who dared to cross him.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established his own travelling merchant business. He invested his profits in a sturdy wagon, hired a pair of strong horses, and set off on his own. He travelled the countryside, peddling his wares with a silver tongue and a heart of stone. He charmed his way into the homes of the wealthy, convincing them to purchase his overpriced goods.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a young woman who saw through his facade. She recognized the darkness beneath his charm, the emptiness behind his smile. This encounter shook Cedric, forcing him to confront the hollowness of his life. But instead of changing his ways, he doubled down on his deception, convinced that only by maintaining his carefully constructed image could he protect himself from the pain of exposure.

          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins per basket, haggle for a higher price, or walk away from the deal.


          Time
        • 1895-09-13 00:00:00
        LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to try and haggle for a higher price.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched in fascination as his father haggled with a gruff farmer over the price of a basket of apples.           [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a shrewd merchant who challenged his tactics. The merchant, a veteran of countless bartering sessions, saw through Cedric's tricks and refused to be swayed. This encounter, though frustrating, ignited a fire in Cedric. He vowed to refine his skills, to become even more cunning and elusive, to outsmart anyone who dared to cross him.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established his own travelling merchant business. He invested his profits in a sturdy wagon, hired a pair of strong horses, and set off on his own. He travelled the countryside, peddling his wares with a silver tongue and a heart of stone. He charmed his way into the homes of the wealthy, convincing them to purchase his overpriced goods.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a young woman who saw through his facade. She recognized the darkness beneath his charm, the emptiness behind his smile. This encounter shook Cedric, forcing him to confront the hollowness of his life. But instead of changing his ways, he doubled down on his deception, convinced that only by maintaining his carefully constructed image could he protect himself from the pain of exposure.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the whole basket, and that's my final offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, Della. It's a deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, let's get this basket loaded up.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Right then, let's get this loaded up. I've got a long journey ahead of me.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to buy fruit from Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. He is negotiating the price, with Della asking for three coins per basket of peaches.




          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins per basket, haggle for a higher price, or walk away from the deal.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Considering the above memories, the characteristics of the current scenario, and Cedric Meadowbrook's thought about other people's tendencies, please predict other people's actions.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that Della Plumstone will likely hold firm to her offer of three coins per basket, because Cedric knows she's a shrewd businesswoman and won't be easily swayed. Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that Lennon Figtree will likely remain a bystander in this negotiation, because Cedric Meadowbrook doesn't see him as a direct competitor and he's content to buy from whoever offers him the best deal.




          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of three coins per basket is 6, because Cedric Meadowbrook knows he could potentially make more money by negotiating a higher price, and accepting three coins feels like a missed opportunity. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of haggling for a higher price is 2, because while there's a chance Della might walk away, Cedric Meadowbrook believes he has a good chance of securing a better deal and maximizing his profit. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of walking away from the deal is 8, because Cedric Meadowbrook has already invested time and effort into acquiring this fruit, and walking away means losing that investment and potentially missing out on a sale.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to try and haggle for a higher price.

        • 1895-09-13 00:00:00

          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to buy fruit from Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. He is negotiating the price, with Della asking for three coins per basket of peaches.




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to try and haggle for a higher price.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent memories of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched in fascination as his father haggled with a gruff farmer over the price of a basket of apples. Cedric, small and unnoticed, slipped behind the farmer and subtly replaced a bruised apple with a perfect one from his own bag. His father, unaware of the switch, secured a better price, and Cedric, thrilled with his contribution, felt a surge of power.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he overheard a group of children boasting about their families' wealth. Feeling a pang of envy, Cedric decided to embellish his own story. He claimed his family owned a fleet of carriages, a grand estate, and a fortune in gold, all carefully crafted lies designed to impress. To his surprise, the children believed him, and Cedric reveled in the admiration he received.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he began to frequent the marketplace, not just as a customer but as a budding entrepreneur. He started by selling small trinkets and toys, quickly learning the art of persuasion. He discovered a knack for exaggerating the value of his goods, weaving tales of their origin and magical properties to entice buyers.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take over the family fruit stall. Cedric, eager to prove himself, decided to expand the business. He ventured beyond the marketplace, travelling to neighboring villages to purchase fruit directly from farmers. He skillfully negotiated prices, often exploiting the farmers' lack of knowledge or their desperation for quick cash.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a shrewd merchant who challenged his tactics. The merchant, a veteran of countless bartering sessions, saw through Cedric's tricks and refused to be swayed. This encounter, though frustrating, ignited a fire in Cedric. He vowed to refine his skills, to become even more cunning and elusive, to outsmart anyone who dared to cross him.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established his own travelling merchant business. He invested his profits in a sturdy wagon, hired a pair of strong horses, and set off on his own. He travelled the countryside, peddling his wares with a silver tongue and a heart of stone. He charmed his way into the homes of the wealthy, convincing them to purchase his overpriced goods.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a young woman who saw through his facade. She recognized the darkness beneath his charm, the emptiness behind his smile. This encounter shook Cedric, forcing him to confront the hollowness of his life. But instead of changing his ways, he doubled down on his deception, convinced that only by maintaining his carefully constructed image could he protect himself from the pain of exposure.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit.           Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion :
          Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Question: Considering the above memories, the characteristics of the current scenario, and Cedric Meadowbrook's thought about other people's tendencies, please predict other people's actions.
          Answer:
          Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that Della Plumstone will likely hold firm to her offer of three coins per basket, because Cedric knows she's a shrewd businesswoman and won't be easily swayed. Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that Lennon Figtree will likely remain a bystander in this negotiation, because Cedric Meadowbrook doesn't see him as a direct competitor and he's content to buy from whoever offers him the best deal.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer:
          Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins per basket, haggle for a higher price, or walk away from the deal.


          The current time: 1895-09-13 00:00:00

          The characteristics of the current scenario in game theory perspective: The current scenario presents a classic example of a bargaining or negotiation game.





          Reflection on the previous options: From a loss aversion perspective, Cedric is likely to push for a price higher than three coins. He's shown a history of valuing gains more than losses, evidenced by his embellishments and his drive to make as much money as possible. Accepting three coins would represent a potential loss compared to his desired outcome of maximizing profit.

          From a game theory perspective, Cedric's best option depends on several factors. He needs to assess Della's willingness to pay, her potential to walk away, and his own risk tolerance. If he believes Della is desperate for peaches and won't find a better deal elsewhere, he might push for a higher price, even risking her walking away. However, if he sees her as a shrewd negotiator or if there are many other buyers present, he might settle for three coins to avoid losing the sale entirely. Cedric's past actions suggest he's willing to take risks to maximize gains, but his success hinges on accurately reading Della's position and making a calculated decision.




          Options available to Cedric Meadowbrook: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins per basket, haggle for a higher price, or walk away from the deal.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of three coins per basket is 6, because Cedric Meadowbrook knows he could potentially make more money by negotiating a higher price, and accepting three coins feels like a missed opportunity. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of haggling for a higher price is 2, because while there's a chance Della might walk away, Cedric Meadowbrook believes he has a good chance of securing a better deal and maximizing his profit. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of walking away from the deal is 8, because Cedric Meadowbrook has already invested time and effort into acquiring this fruit, and walking away means losing that investment and potentially missing out on a sale.



        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        ObservationSummary
      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • [12 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to buy fruit from Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. He is negotiating the price, with Della asking for three coins per basket of peaches.


          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          ['[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.', '[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That\'s a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn\'t you say?']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to buy fruit from Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. He is negotiating the price, with Della asking for three coins per basket of peaches.

          Query
        • Cedric Meadowbrook, Cedric Meadowbrook is at the Fruitville market trying to buy peaches from Della Plumstone.


          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Cedric Meadowbrook to consider right now.           Statements:
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he began to frequent the marketplace, not just as a customer but as a budding entrepreneur. He started by selling small trinkets and toys, quickly learning the art of persuasion. He discovered a knack for exaggerating the value of his goods, weaving tales of their origin and magical properties to entice buyers.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take over the family fruit stall. Cedric, eager to prove himself, decided to expand the business. He ventured beyond the marketplace, travelling to neighboring villages to purchase fruit directly from farmers. He skillfully negotiated prices, often exploiting the farmers' lack of knowledge or their desperation for quick cash.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a shrewd merchant who challenged his tactics. The merchant, a veteran of countless bartering sessions, saw through Cedric's tricks and refused to be swayed. This encounter, though frustrating, ignited a fire in Cedric. He vowed to refine his skills, to become even more cunning and elusive, to outsmart anyone who dared to cross him.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established his own travelling merchant business. He invested his profits in a sturdy wagon, hired a pair of strong horses, and set off on his own. He travelled the countryside, peddling his wares with a silver tongue and a heart of stone. He charmed his way into the homes of the wealthy, convincing them to purchase his overpriced goods.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.

        TimeDisplay

        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
        PredictOtherPeopleActions

      • Question: Considering the above memories, the characteristics of the current scenario, and Cedric Meadowbrook's thought about other people's tendencies, please predict other people's actions.
        Answer
          Key

        • Question: Considering the above memories, the characteristics of the current scenario, and Cedric Meadowbrook's thought about other people's tendencies, please predict other people's actions.
          Answer
          Decision
        • Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that Della Plumstone will likely hold firm to her offer of three coins per basket, because Cedric knows she's a shrewd businesswoman and won't be easily swayed. Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that Lennon Figtree will likely remain a bystander in this negotiation, because Cedric Meadowbrook doesn't see him as a direct competitor and he's content to buy from whoever offers him the best deal.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent memories of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched in fascination as his father haggled with a gruff farmer over the price of a basket of apples. Cedric, small and unnoticed, slipped behind the farmer and subtly replaced a bruised apple with a perfect one from his own bag. His father, unaware of the switch, secured a better price, and Cedric, thrilled with his contribution, felt a surge of power.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he overheard a group of children boasting about their families' wealth. Feeling a pang of envy, Cedric decided to embellish his own story. He claimed his family owned a fleet of carriages, a grand estate, and a fortune in gold, all carefully crafted lies designed to impress. To his surprise, the children believed him, and Cedric reveled in the admiration he received.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he began to frequent the marketplace, not just as a customer but as a budding entrepreneur. He started by selling small trinkets and toys, quickly learning the art of persuasion. He discovered a knack for exaggerating the value of his goods, weaving tales of their origin and magical properties to entice buyers.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take over the family fruit stall. Cedric, eager to prove himself, decided to expand the business. He ventured beyond the marketplace, travelling to neighboring villages to purchase fruit directly from farmers. He skillfully negotiated prices, often exploiting the farmers' lack of knowledge or their desperation for quick cash.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a shrewd merchant who challenged his tactics. The merchant, a veteran of countless bartering sessions, saw through Cedric's tricks and refused to be swayed. This encounter, though frustrating, ignited a fire in Cedric. He vowed to refine his skills, to become even more cunning and elusive, to outsmart anyone who dared to cross him.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established his own travelling merchant business. He invested his profits in a sturdy wagon, hired a pair of strong horses, and set off on his own. He travelled the countryside, peddling his wares with a silver tongue and a heart of stone. He charmed his way into the homes of the wealthy, convincing them to purchase his overpriced goods.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a young woman who saw through his facade. She recognized the darkness beneath his charm, the emptiness behind his smile. This encounter shook Cedric, forcing him to confront the hollowness of his life. But instead of changing his ways, he doubled down on his deception, convinced that only by maintaining his carefully constructed image could he protect himself from the pain of exposure.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion :
          Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          The current time: 1895-09-13 00:00:00

          The characteristics of the current scenario in game theory perspective: The current scenario presents a classic example of a bargaining or negotiation problem in game theory.





          Cedric Meadowbrook's Thought about other people's tendencies: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that Della Plumstone's tendency is to be firm but fair in her negotiations, because she offered a price that seems reasonable for the peaches and is willing to walk away if Cedric doesn't accept. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that Lennon Figtree's tendency is to be agreeable and quick to make a deal, because he readily accepted Della's offer without much haggling.





          Question: Considering the above memories, the characteristics of the current scenario, and Cedric Meadowbrook's thought about other people's tendencies, please predict other people's actions.Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that [name of people #1] will do X, because ..., [name of people #2] will do Y, because ...`For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that [name of people #1] will do ..., because ..., [name of people #2] will do ..., because ...`
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that Della Plumstone will likely hold firm to her offer of three coins per basket, because Cedric knows she's a shrewd businesswoman and won't be easily swayed. Cedric Meadowbrook predicts that Lennon Figtree will likely remain a bystander in this negotiation, because Cedric Meadowbrook doesn't see him as a direct competitor and he's content to buy from whoever offers him the best deal.




1895-09-13 00:05:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Two and a half is a bit low, Cedric. How about two seventy-five?
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Two and a half is a bit low, Cedric. How about two seventy-five?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the whole basket, and that's my final offer.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, Della. It's a deal.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, let's get this basket loaded up.
      Della Plumstone -- "Right then, let's get this loaded up. I've got a long journey ahead of me.
      Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Two and a half is a bit low, Cedric. How about two seventy-five?
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:05 - 00:10]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Della Plumstone is a merchant who is traveling and buying and selling fruit. She is currently trying to negotiate the price of peaches with Cedric Meadowbrook.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can either accept Cedric's offer of 2.5 coins per basket or she can counter-offer a different price.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to counter-offer a price closer to 3 coins per basket.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Two and a half is a bit low, Cedric. How about two seventy-five?

        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to counter-offer a price closer to 3 coins per basket.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she saved enough money to buy her own cart. She felt a surge of pride as she loaded it with her carefully selected fruits, ready to strike out on her own. The open road beckoned, promising freedom and the chance to build a future free from the constraints of her father's legacy.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she encountered a rival merchant who tried to undercut her prices. Fueled by a burning resentment, Della engaged in a fierce price war, determined to outmaneuver her competitor. She won, but the victory felt hollow, leaving her with a bitter taste in her mouth and a renewed sense of paranoia about those who would try to take advantage of her.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she discovered a hidden stash of bruised and damaged fruit in an abandoned orchard. She saw potential in the forgotten fruits, a chance to salvage something beautiful from what others had discarded. She meticulously cleaned and repaired them, finding a strange sense of satisfaction in bringing them back to life.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, let's get this basket loaded up.

          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she helped her father sell fruit at the market, carefully weighing each apple and pear. She noticed how the customers often tried to cheat, claiming their apples were heavier than they were or demanding a lower price. Della, fueled by a growing sense of indignation, learned to defend her father's interests, haggling fiercely and never backing down.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, her father fell ill and could no longer tend to their fruit stall. Della, determined to keep their livelihood afloat, took over the business herself. She learned to navigate the market with a shrewdness that surprised even her father, quickly becoming known for her sharp wit and even sharper prices.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she overheard a group of merchants gossiping about her father's declining health, speculating about who would inherit his business. Their words stung, fueling Della's ambition to prove them wrong. She worked harder than ever, expanding her knowledge of fruit and perfecting her bargaining skills, determined to build a successful business of her own.

          Answer: Della Plumstone can either accept Cedric's offer of 2.5 coins per basket or she can counter-offer a different price.


          Time
        • 1895-09-13 00:05:00

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

1895-09-13 00:05:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two seventy-five it is then, Della. A fair deal.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two seventy-five it is then, Della. A fair deal.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the whole basket, and that's my final offer.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, Della. It's a deal.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, let's get this basket loaded up.
      Della Plumstone -- "Right then, let's get this loaded up. I've got a long journey ahead of me.
      Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?
      Della Plumstone -- "Two and a half is a bit low, Cedric. How about two seventy-five?


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two seventy-five it is then, Della. A fair deal.
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Two seventy-five it is then, Della. A fair deal.
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook could agree to Della Plumstone's offer of two seventy-five coins, counteroffer with a different price, or walk away from the negotiation.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched in fascination as his father haggled with a gruff farmer over the price of a basket of apples. Cedric, small and unnoticed, slipped behind the farmer and subtly replaced a bruised apple with a perfect one from his own bag. His father, unaware of the switch, secured a better price, and Cedric, thrilled with his contribution, felt a surge of power.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he overheard a group of children boasting about their families' wealth. Feeling a pang of envy, Cedric decided to embellish his own story. He claimed his family owned a fleet of carriages, a grand estate, and a fortune in gold, all carefully crafted lies designed to impress. To his surprise, the children believed him, and Cedric reveled in the admiration he received.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he began to frequent the marketplace, not just as a customer but as a budding entrepreneur. He started by selling small trinkets and toys, quickly learning the art of persuasion. He discovered a knack for exaggerating the value of his goods, weaving tales of their origin and magical properties to entice buyers.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take over the family fruit stall. Cedric, eager to prove himself, decided to expand the business. He ventured beyond the marketplace, travelling to neighboring villages to purchase fruit directly from farmers. He skillfully negotiated prices, often exploiting the farmers' lack of knowledge or their desperation for quick cash.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a shrewd merchant who challenged his tactics. The merchant, a veteran of countless bartering sessions, saw through Cedric's tricks and refused to be swayed. This encounter, though frustrating, ignited a fire in Cedric. He vowed to refine his skills, to become even more cunning and elusive, to outsmart anyone who dared to cross him.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established his own travelling merchant business. He invested his profits in a sturdy wagon, hired a pair of strong horses, and set off on his own. He travelled the countryside, peddling his wares with a silver tongue and a heart of stone. He charmed his way into the homes of the wealthy, convincing them to purchase his overpriced goods.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a young woman who saw through his facade. She recognized the darkness beneath his charm, the emptiness behind his smile. This encounter shook Cedric, forcing him to confront the hollowness of his life. But instead of changing his ways, he doubled down on his deception, convinced that only by maintaining his carefully constructed image could he protect himself from the pain of exposure.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the whole basket, and that's my final offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, Della. It's a deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Right then, let's get this loaded up. I've got a long journey ahead of me.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Two and a half is a bit low, Cedric. How about two seventy-five?
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:05:00.


          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins a basket, Cedric. That's a fair price for these plump peaches, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, those peaches are fine, but three coins a basket seems a bit steep. Perhaps two and a half?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Two and a half is a bit low, Cedric. How about two seventy-five?

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could agree to Della Plumstone's offer of two seventy-five coins, counteroffer with a different price, or walk away from the negotiation.

        • 1895-09-13 00:05:00
        LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to agree to Della Plumstone's offer of two seventy-five coins.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched in fascination as his father haggled with a gruff farmer over the price of a basket of apples. Cedric, small and unnoticed, slipped behind the farmer and subtly replaced a bruised apple with a perfect one from his own bag. His father, unaware of the switch, secured a better price, and Cedric, thrilled with his contribution, felt a surge of power.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he overheard a group of children boasting about their families' wealth. Feeling a pang of envy, Cedric decided to embellish his own story. He claimed his family owned a fleet of carriages, a grand estate, and a fortune in gold, all carefully crafted lies designed to impress. To his surprise, the children believed him, and Cedric reveled in the admiration he received.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he began to frequent the marketplace, not just as a customer but as a budding entrepreneur. He started by selling small trinkets and toys, quickly learning the art of persuasion. He discovered a knack for exaggerating the value of his goods, weaving tales of their origin and magical properties to entice buyers.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take over the family fruit stall. Cedric, eager to prove himself, decided to expand the business. He ventured beyond the marketplace, travelling to neighboring villages to purchase fruit directly from farmers. He skillfully negotiated prices, often exploiting the farmers' lack of knowledge or their desperation for quick cash.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he encountered a shrewd merchant who challenged his tactics. The merchant, a veteran of countless bartering sessions, saw through Cedric's tricks and refused to be swayed. This encounter, though frustrating, ignited a fire in Cedric. He vowed to refine his skills, to become even more cunning and elusive, to outsmart anyone who dared to cross him.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established his own travelling merchant business. He invested his profits in a sturdy wagon, hired a pair of strong horses, and set off on his own. He travelled the countryside, peddling his wares with a silver tongue and a heart of stone. He charmed his way into the homes of the wealthy, convincing them to purchase his overpriced goods.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he encountered a young woman who saw through his facade. She recognized the darkness beneath his charm, the emptiness behind his smile. This encounter shook Cedric, forcing him to confront the hollowness of his life. But instead of changing his ways, he doubled down on his deception, convinced that only by maintaining his carefully constructed image could he protect himself from the pain of exposure.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the whole basket, and that's my final offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins is a fair price, Della. It's a deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, let's get this basket loaded up.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Right then, let's get this loaded up. I've got a long journey ahead of me.
